Corma*, S. Iborra, J. Primo, F. Rey Instituto de Tecnologia Quimica UPV-CSIC, Universidad Politecnica de Valencia, Camino de Vera s/n, 46022 Valencia,Spain Received 3 November 1993; revised 3 March 1994; accepted 3 March 1994 Abstract Citronitril was obtained starting from ethyl cyanoacetate and benzylacetone using solid base catalysts. Hydrotalcites were found to carry out this reaction efficiently. The hydrotalcite catalyst was optimized from the point of view of its textural properties, composition ,i.e. Ca, Mg, and Zn as divalent cations, and Al/ (Al +Mg) in the case of the magnesium-aluminium hydrotalcites. The influence of water, reaction temperature and polarity of the solvent on conversion and selectivity was studied. Keywords: Base catalyst; Hydrotalcite catalyst; Citronitril synthesis 1. Introduction The Knoevenagel condensation is a very useful reaction in organic synthesis. It allows to prepare molecules containing a double bond conjugated with a carbonyl function by condensation of a molecule with a carbonyl group and another with activated methylenic groups. These reactions are catalyzed by bases such as ammonia, ammonium salts or primary and secondary amines [ 1 ] . Other catalysts such as anionic resins [ 2 ] , KF and CsF [ 3,4 ] and TiC14 [ 5,6 ] have also been used. However, the tendency in the last years is to develop environmentally friendly solid catalysts that can be easily separated and recycled. Among them, La203 and Ce02 supported on silica gel [ 7 ] , barium hydroxide [ 8,9 ] magnesium and aluminium oxides [ 10-12 ] , montmorillonite [ 13 ] , silicon oxinitride [ 14] , zeolites [ 15 ] , sepiolites [ 16 ] , hydrotalcites [ 17 ] , and amino groups immobilized on silica gel have been investigated as basic catalysts [ 18 ] . *Corresponding author. 0926-860X/94/$07.00 1994 Elsevier Science B.V. All rights reserved 216 A. Corma et al. /Applied Catalysis A: General 114 (1994) 215-225 Here, we have studied the production of citronitril [ 19,20] (5-phenyl-3-methyl2-pentenenitrile) (4, see Scheme 1) which is a fine chemical considered of commercial interest in the perfume industry as well as for detergents and soaps. The reaction was carried on a series of solid base catalysts of increasing basic strengths, the textural and chemical composition of catalysts, as well as the reaction conditions, have been optimized. 2. Experimental 2.1. Materials The basic catalysts studied are CsNaX zeolite, Cs-sepiolite, MgO, and hydrotalcites containing a divalent cation: Mg, Ca and Zn. The CsNaX zeolite was prepared by a repeated exchange of a NaX zeolite (13 x ) with an aqueous solution of CsCl (0.5 M), at room temperature. The CsNa-sepiolite was prepared starting from a sodium form of sepiolite [ 21 ] , and carrying out the ion exchange using an aqueous solution of CsCl, at room temperature. The final sepiolite sample contained (1.7 wt.-%) and (6.3 wt.-%) of Cs and Na respectively, both of them located in the channels of the sepiolite. The magnesium hydrotalcites were prepared by coprecipitation of an aqueous solution of magnesium and aluminium (solution A) with a second solution (B) of NaOH and Na2C03- The concentration of Mg (N03) 2 - 6H20 + Al (N03) 3 - 9H20 was 1.5 M; the ratios of the two, Al/ (A1 + Mg), of the different catalyst samples are given in Table 1. The concentration of Na2C03 in solution B was 1 M, and the concentration of NaOH was adjusted in order to achieve a final pH of 10 or 13 in the gel. The gel composition as well as the final pH are given in Table 1. All the gels were crystallized under hydrothermal conditions for 18 h at the different temperatures given in Table 1. After this they were filtered and washed with distilled water until no more carbonates were detected and the pH of the rinse water was 7. Finally, the solids were dried at 333 K for 24 h. In order to obtain the catalytic active forms of the magnesium hydrotalcites, they were calcined at 723 K for 18 h. In this case the time for mixing solution A, containing Caz+ and A13+, and solution B was 15 min, and immediately after this, the precipitate was filtered and washed until no more N03- could be detected and the pH was 7. The X3-. This sample was heated at 723 K in nitrogen atmosphere in order to remove the nitrates, while avoiding formation of CaC03. The resultant material displayed a X-ray diffraction (XRD) pattern of well crystallized CaO on another phase which was amorphous. The textural properties of the oxide formed are presented in Table 2. In an analogous way as that presented above, a zinc hydrotalcite (ZnA16) was prepared by mixing a solution of zinc and aluminium ( (Zn+Al) -1.5 M) with a 2 M NaN03 solution containing NaOH. The composition of the gel obtained is given in Table 1. This gel was crystallized under hydrothermal conditions at 353 K for 18 h, and then filtered and dried as described above. The XRD indicates that an Zn-A1 hydrotalcite was obtained. After calcination, the presence of well crystallized ZnO was detected in the solid. The textural properties and chemical composition of this material are given in Table 2. A high surface area MgO sample was also prepared, by thermal decomposition of magnesium oxalate at 873 in vacuum [ 22 ] for 6 h, and the textural properties are given in Table 2. 2.2. Reaction procedure The reaction was carried out in a glass reactor, magnetically stirred, and heated in a silicone bath. The reaction procedure was as follows. A solvent-free mixture of benzylacetone (7 mmol) and ethyl cyanoacetate (18 mmol) was heated at 463 K, while stirring, in the batch reactor. When the temperature was stable, the catalyst (3 wt.-%) was added. At this moment the reaction started and samples were taken at different reaction times to follow the progress of the reaction. The reaction products were analyzed by gas chromatography-mass spectrometry (GC-MS) 218 A. Corma et al. /Applied Catalysis A: General 114 (1994) 215-225 (Hewlett-Packard 5988 A mass spectrometer connected with a 25-m capillary column of 5% cross-linked phenylmethylsilicone) and by 'H- spectroscopy (Varian 360 EM spectrometer). The course of the reaction was followed by GC (Hewlett-Packard 5890 apparatus with a flame ionization detector and using the same column as above) by taking and analysing samples at several times ranging from 0.1 to 24 h. The catalyst recovered in each sample was always repetitively washed with dichloromethane, and the extracted products were also analyzed and considered in the mass balance. Under the reaction conditions used here, it was detected that some hydrolysis and decomposition of 2 (Scheme 1) occurs, as indicated by the presence of acetonitrile in the products. Owing to this, an stoichiometric excess of 2 was always used, and the conversion was calculated with respect to reactant 1. The hydrolysis reaction was carried out in a Teflon@ lined stainless steel autoclave, magnetically stirred, and heated in a silicone bath. A solution of ester 3 (50 mg) in toluene (2 ml), water (different amounts) and the catalyst (50 mg) was poured into the autoclave, the suspension was heated for 15 h at different temperatures. The reaction products were analyzed by GC-MS. 3. Results and discussion The formation of citronitril (4) from benzylacetone (1) and ethyl cyanoacetate (2) involves several reaction steps (Scheme 1) . In the first one, reactants 1 and 2 condensate to give the E and Z isomers of ethyl 2-cyan-5-phenyl-3-methyl-2hexenoate (3) plus water. In order to obtain citronitril (4), ethyl 2-cyan-5-phenyl3-methyl-2-hexenoate (3) must undergo hydrolysis, followed by decarboxylation, and in this way a mixture of the E and Z isomers of the desired 5-phenyl-3-methyl2-pentenonitrile (4) is obtained. 11 catalyst IH3/CN PhCH2CH2-C-CH3 + NC-CHZ-C0OEt - Ph-CHZCH2-C=C + H20 [1] \COOEt IH3/CN hydrolysis CH3 Ph-CH2CH2-C=C`COOEt ----f ph_CHzCH2-C=CH-CN _COZ 4 Scheme 1. Results from Table 3 indicate that the zeolite, sepiolite Mg-hydrotalcite and Mg0 are quite active for the condensation reaction. The order of reactivity is MgHT > Mg0 > sepiolite > zeolite. However, when the surface area is taken into consideration, it can be seen that the activity of the zeolite is much lower than that of any of the other three catalysts. These results agree with a previous work [ 15-17] in which it was indicated that, besides the possible geometric constrains present in the zeolite, its basicity, measured as the capacity for abstracting acidic hydrogens in activated methylenic compounds, is in the range of pK 9-10.7 for the CsNaX zeolite, while for Cs-sepiolite and magnesium hydrotalcite the value goes up to 13.3 and 16.6, respectively. However, it should be remarked that under these conditions none of the catalysts is able to extensively hydrolyse and decarboxylate the condensation product 3, and therefore the yields of citronitril obtained are very low. Influence of chemical composition and textural properties of hydrotalcite on catalytic activity At this point, we concentrated our attention on the most active catalysts, i.e. the hydrotalcite. Thus, the influence of the chemical composition [the Al/ (Al + Mg) ratio] on the catalyst activity was studied. Some authors [23] have reported that C02 temperature-programmed desorption indicates that the incorporation of aluminium into MgO suppresses the formation of high-strength basic sites normally associated with pure MgO. Somewhat different conclusions were formulated by others [24,25 ] who claimed that aluminium plays a role in contributing to the appearance of strong basic sites in the compound prepared from hydrotalcite composition. Such a strong basicity was not exhibited by the MgO alone. In other words, it appears that by increasing the amount of aluminium in the hydrotalcite structure, the total number of basic sites decreases but the proportion of the stronger ones increases. If this is so we may expect to find an optimum in activity for a given base catalyzed reaction at a given A1 / (Al + Mg). The position of this maximum will depend on the basic strength necessary to catalyze that particular reaction. 220 A. For the reaction studied here, in which the methylenic group is strongly activated by the cyano and the acetoacetate groups, it should be relatively easy for the catalyst to generate the carbanion by extracting the proton. Therefore, basic sites with weak to medium strength should already be able to perform the reaction, and consequently the maximum in activity should be shifted to relatively low aluminium containing samples. Indeed, the results presented in Fig. 1 clearly show that the maximum in activity appears between the pure MgO sample and the magnesium hydrotalcite with the lowest aluminium content. Furthermore, it can be seen that when the aluminium content increases, the catalytic activity for the condensation reaction strongly decreases. In the case of MgO, and Mg-Al oxides derived from hydrotalcites, the basicity can be associated with hydroxyl groups and with framework oxygens [261. In principle these should be stronger than the hydroxyl groups, and among these the basic strength should be different depending on the coordination number of the oxygen, i.e. if the oxygen considered is in a corner, on an edge or on a crystal face [ 27 ] . If it is so, one will, by changing the crystallite size of the material, change the relative amount of the different basic sites, and therefore an effect on catalytic activity should be expected. Samples C13 and C14 were prepared by changing the crystallization temperature in the synthesis procedure (Table 1) . They have the same chemical composition, but different crystallite sizes. When their catalytic properties were measured in the condensation reaction, small differences in activity were observed between the two samples, probably as a consequence of the relatively weak basicity needed to carry out the reaction under study, which in turn makes all the different types of oxygen active (Table 3) . Finally, the basicity of the hydrotalcite catalyst was also changed here by introducing divalent cations of different electronegativity (Tables 1 and 2). The results presented in Table 4 indicate that the calcium containing catalyst gives a lower conversion than the magnesium hydrotalcite. However, the surface A. Therefore, if the activity per surface area is calculated, it can be seen that the catalyst derived from the calcium hydrotalcite gives a much higher activity than those derived from magnesium hydrotalcites. However, it should be taken into account that the XRD diagram of the calcined calcium hydrotalcite showed that a considerable amount of calcium was segregated forming CaO. Therefore, we can not consider the calcined calcium hydrotalcite as a mixed Ca-A1 oxide, but as a mixture of CaO, and a mixed Ca-A1 oxide rich in aluminium. The same can be said for the zinc sample, but in this material, and owing to the lower basicity of the zinc, its activity, even per unit of surface area, is considerably lower. Nevertheless, it should be pointed out that when looking at the formation of citronitril, low yields were always obtained, and only the calcium form showed a reasonable activity per unit surface area. 3.2. Hydrolysis and decarboxylation of ethyl 2-cyano-5 phenyl-3-methyl-2 hexenoate (3) The hydrolysis of the ethyl 2-cyano-5-phenyl-3-methyl-2-hexenoate (3) obtained previously, and the decarboxylation of the acid formed can be also catalyzed by bases. Thus, a conventional hydrolysis experiment was carried out by treating the ester 3 in a 20% aqueous solution of NaOH. When the reaction was carried out at room temperature for 24 h, the reactant remained unaltered. When the reaction mixture was heated for 4 h at 100 C, 95% of the ester disappeared, but only 1 % citronitril was formed. The main reaction occurring under these conditions was the reverse Knoevenagel giving benzylacetone and ethyl cyanoacetate (Scheme 2). However, at the reaction temperature used, the first equilibrium should be shifted towards the condensation, and high levels of decomposition of the ester to ethyl cyanoacetate and benzylacetone should not be observed. Unfortunately, under these experimental conditions the ethyl cyanoacetate decomposes, and this produces the shift of the first equilibrium toward the original products. After 15 h, 25% conversion was observed with 30% selectivity to citronitril. Conclusions The first step for the production of citronitril, i.e. the condensation of 1 with 2 is efficiently carried out by hydrotalcites. The more basic calcium-aluminium hydrotalcite is more active, per unit surface area, than magnesium-aluminium hydrotalcites, and these are more active than a zinc-aluminium hydrotalcite. However, owing to the higher surface area of Mg-Al hydrotalcites its activity per unit weight of catalyst is the highest. In magnesium-aluminium hydrotalcites a maximum in activity is found for samples with a ratio Al/ (Al + Mg) = 0.25 for which an optimum between the total number and the strength distribution of basic sites exist for this reaction. A minor effect of hydrotalcite crystal size on activity was found. The second reaction step, i.e. the hydrolysis of the ester and finally decarboxylation of the acid formed, is a more demanding reaction from the point of view of the catalyst. The water present and reaction temperature play an important role for maximizing the production of citronitril. When they were optimized, high conversions with selectivities for citronitril close to 50% were obtained in a one-pot reaction. References [ 1 ] G. coredata.dc:description: Citronitril was obtained starting from ethyl cyanoacetate and benzylacetone using solid base catalysts. Hydrotalcites were found to carry out this reaction efficiently. The hydrotalcite catalyst was optimized from the point of view of its textural properties, composition ,i.e. Ca, Mg, and Zn as divalent cations, and Al/(Al+Mg) in the case of the magnesium-aluminium hydrotalcites. The influence of water, reaction temperature and polarity of the solvent on conversion and selectivity was studied.
coredata.dc:title: One-step synthesis of citronitril on hydrotalcite derived base catalysts
